Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
Students will study how the structure and dynamics of proteins explains their biological function and will cover a range of concepts and techniques. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of integrative structural biology and the extent different approaches and concepts are complementary to each other and help explain the structural basis of biological processes at the molecular level.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory modules to be coupled with practical exercises that involve analysis/interpretation/visualisation of example data sets.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

• Prepare students for structural biology concepts that give a deep understanding of macromolecule structure, dynamics and function and their relation to biology.

• Enable students to appreciate the variety of techniques used to collect structural biology data and to use this data to understand biology.

• Enable students to visualise, analyse and interpret structural biological data in the context of a range of biological and biomedical systems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module examines how the structure and dynamics of proteins explains their biological function. Includes concepts in protein folding, protein interactions/specificity and protein regulation. Protein production and rapid biophysical characterisation approaches will be studied that include techniques for studying protein interactions and the insights they give to biology. Biological systems that require large conformational changes and allostery including large complexes/machines will be introduced. Biological insights gained from structural techniques such as x-ray crystallography, cryoEM and protein bioinformatics as well as techniques that study the dynamics of proteins such as NMR and molecular dynamics will be taught. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of integrative structural biology and the extent different approaches and concepts are complementary to each other and help explain the structural basis of biological processes at the molecular level. The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops and assessed by two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1. Structural biology concepts in protein folding, protein interactions/specificity and protein regulation
• Pymol visualisation
• Protein interaction bioinformatics
• Protein domain structure and function

Topic 2. Protein production and biophysical characterisation approaches to include techniques for studying protein interactions.
• Engineering recombinant proteins
• In vitro techniques such as ITC, NanoDSF, Chemical denaturation

Topic 3. Biological insights from proteins that require large conformational changes and allostery
• Conformational selection vs induced fit
• Allosteric regulation
• Large Conformational changes for function
• How techniques such as x-ray crystallography can probe these systems.

Topic 4. Biological insights from multi-protein complexes/machines
• Assembly and function
• How techniques such as cryo-EM can probe these systems.

Topic 5. Biological insights from computational techniques that predict protein structure and function
• May include artificial intelligence methods such as AlphaFold.
• Protein bioinformatics

Topic 6. Biological insights from protein dynamics, protein disorder and conformational exchange
• Folding on binding
• Linear motifs
• Dynamic protein complexes
• How methods such as NMR and molecular dynamics can probe these systems.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be complementary computational workshops. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory-delivery to be explored and applied in small groups and will use bioinformatic approaches.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include paper analysis and discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Computer Workshops
Description: Application of lecture material using data to analyse, interpret and visualise
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignment.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments.

Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around structural biology concepts and data interpretation.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around structural biology concepts and data interpretation. Must include an original infographic/figure.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Teaching Method 2 – Computer Workshops
Description: Application of lecture material using data to analyse, interpret and visualise
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignment.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments.

Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around structural biology concepts and data interpretation.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around structural biology concepts and data interpretation. Must include an original infographic/figure.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
Students will study how the structure and dynamics of proteins explains their biological function and will cover a range of concepts and techniques. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of integrative structural biology and the extent different approaches and concepts are complementary to each other and help explain the structural basis of biological processes at the molecular level.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory modules to be coupled with practical exercises that involve analysis/interpretation/visualisation of example data sets.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

• Prepare students for structural biology concepts that give a deep understanding of macromolecule structure, dynamics and function and their relation to biology.

• Enable students to appreciate the variety of techniques used to collect structural biology data and to use this data to understand biology.

• Enable students to visualise, analyse and interpret structural biological data in the context of a range of biological and biomedical systems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module examines how the structure and dynamics of proteins explains their biological function. Includes concepts in protein folding, protein interactions/specificity and protein regulation. Protein production and rapid biophysical characterisation approaches will be studied that include techniques for studying protein interactions and the insights they give to biology. Biological systems that require large conformational changes and allostery including large complexes/machines will be introduced. Biological insights gained from structural techniques such as x-ray crystallography, cryoEM and protein bioinformatics as well as techniques that study the dynamics of proteins such as NMR and molecular dynamics will be taught. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of integrative structural biology and the extent different approaches and concepts are complementary to each other and help explain the structural basis of biological processes at the molecular level. The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops and assessed by two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1. Structural biology concepts in protein folding, protein interactions/specificity and protein regulation
• Pymol visualisation
• Protein interaction bioinformatics
• Protein domain structure and function

Topic 2. Protein production and biophysical characterisation approaches to include techniques for studying protein interactions.
• Engineering recombinant proteins
• In vitro techniques such as ITC, NanoDSF, Chemical denaturation

Topic 3. Biological insights from proteins that require large conformational changes and allostery
• Conformational selection vs induced fit
• Allosteric regulation
• Large Conformational changes for function
• How techniques such as x-ray crystallography can probe these systems.

Topic 4. Biological insights from multi-protein complexes/machines
• Assembly and function
• How techniques such as cryo-EM can probe these systems.

Topic 5. Biological insights from computational techniques that predict protein structure and function
• May include artificial intelligence methods such as AlphaFold.
• Protein bioinformatics

Topic 6. Biological insights from protein dynamics, protein disorder and conformational exchange
• Folding on binding
• Linear motifs
• Dynamic protein complexes
• How methods such as NMR and molecular dynamics can probe these systems.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be complementary computational workshops. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory-delivery to be explored and applied in small groups and will use bioinformatic approaches.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include paper analysis and discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Computer Workshops
Description: Application of lecture material using data to analyse, interpret and visualise
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignment.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments.

Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around structural biology concepts and data interpretation.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around structural biology concepts and data interpretation. Must include an original infographic/figure.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
